Bacalar

Bacalar is home to Mexico's most breathtaking natural wonder—the 'Lagoon of Seven Colors,' a 55km fr...

Quick Facts About Bacalar

Best Time to Visit
November to April
Average Temperature
27°C (81°F)
Known For
Lagoon of Seven Colors swimming, Stromatolites—ancient living fossils
Airport Code
Chetumal (CTM) - 40 min

About Bacalar

Bacalar is home to Mexico's most breathtaking natural wonder—the 'Lagoon of Seven Colors,' a 55km freshwater lake displaying an impossible spectrum of blues and turquoises. This tranquil Pueblo Mágico offers a serene escape from the Riviera Maya crowds, with laid-back swimming, boat tours, cenotes, and a growing eco-conscious tourism scene.

Hidden in the far south of Quintana Roo, just 40km from the Belize border, Bacalar remained off the tourist trail for decades while the northern Riviera Maya exploded with development. The lagoon, formed by interconnected cenotes and groundwater, displays an extraordinary range of colors—from pale turquoise to deep sapphire—caused by varying depths, white limestone bottom, and aquatic vegetation called stromatolites (some of the oldest life forms on Earth). The small town of Bacalar, designated a Pueblo Mágico (Magic Town), sits along the lagoon's western shore with a Spanish colonial fort, colorful streets, and an increasing number of boutique hotels and restaurants catering to travelers seeking something different. Swimming in the lagoon's warm, impossibly clear water is a transcendent experience, best enjoyed from a boat tour visiting the Pirates' Canal or the cenote Cenote Azul. Bacalar is also a popular stop on the route between the Riviera Maya and Belize or Guatemala, offering a perfect place to decompress from the party scene to the north.

Practical Information

Frequently Asked Questions About Bacalar

Why is Bacalar called the Lagoon of Seven Colors?
The lagoon displays multiple shades of blue and turquoise due to varying depths (up to 90m in cenote areas), white sandy/limestone bottom reflecting sunlight differently, aquatic vegetation (stromatolites), and the angle of the sun. The range of colors—from pale aqua to deep sapphire—is genuinely spectacular.
How do I get to Bacalar?
From Cancún: 4-5 hour drive or ADO bus. From Tulum: 2.5 hours by car or bus. From Chetumal airport: 40 minutes by car. Many visitors include Bacalar on their way to/from Belize. Having a rental car gives more flexibility for the region.
Can you swim in the Bacalar Lagoon?
Yes! The lagoon is freshwater and perfect for swimming. Access from hotels with lagoon frontage, public areas in town, boat tours, and cenotes like Cenote Azul. The water is warm, clear, and shallow in many areas. No stinging jellyfish or waves.
What are stromatolites and why are they important?
Stromatolites are ancient bacterial formations—literally some of the oldest life forms on Earth, dating back billions of years. Bacalar's lagoon has living stromatolites that must be protected. Swimming near them is allowed but touching is forbidden. They're a unique feature that makes Bacalar special.
How many days should I spend in Bacalar?
2-3 days is ideal: a boat tour of the lagoon, swimming and paddleboarding, visiting cenotes, and relaxing. The slow pace is the point—don't rush. Bacalar is great for decompressing after the busier Riviera Maya destinations.
Is Bacalar developed or remote?
Bacalar is growing but remains low-key compared to Tulum or Playa del Carmen. The town has good restaurants, boutique hotels, and amenities, but no clubs or party scene. ATMs are limited—bring cash. The pace is deliberately tranquil and eco-conscious.
